name: expire
content:
expire verb
(END)
Add to word list
Add to word list
C2 [ I ] If something that lasts for a fixed length of time expires, it comes to an end or stops being in use: My passport expires next month. The contract between the two companies will expire at the end of the year.

expire verb
(DIE)
[ I ] literary to die: He ceased to breathe, gently expiring without any struggle at the age of 90. In 1936 the last Tasmanian tiger breathed its final breath and expired in a zoo in Hobart.

to stop livingdieMy dog died last week.die a natural/violent deathShe dies a natural death at home, surrounded by loved ones.pass awayHe passed away peacefully in hospital.pass onI'm sorry to hear that your grandfather has passed on.passUS My father passed last year.

expire verb
(BREATHE OUT)
[ I or T ]
  medical , biology
  specialized to breathe out or to breathe air out: The patient inhales as much air as possible and then expires with maximum effort. The device measures the amount of carbon dioxide expired by the patient's lungs.

expire verb [I]
(END)
Add to word list
Add to word list
(of something that lasts for a fixed length of time) to end or stop being in use: My passport will expire next year.
expire verb [I]
(DIE)
fml to die
Add to word list
Add to word list
to come to an end after a fixed length of time: a contract/lease/licence expires This offer expires on 31 March 2012.set/scheduled/due to expire The warranty period is due to expire at the end of November. Under current law, the state's earned-income tax credit would expire after this year.
FINANCE, STOCK MARKET if an option (= the right to buy or sell particular shares) expires, it can no longer be exercised (= used): The investment options expire on February 5.
